title: What will be the closing yield for the 30-year U.S. Treasury on 31 December 2020?
preds:
Still around 1.70% for some days.
"Jamie Dimon [CEO JPMorgan] says he wouldn’t touch Treasurys with a 10-foot pole at these rates" https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/08/jamie-dimon-says-he-wouldnt-touch-treasuries-with-a-10-foot-pole-at-these-rates.html

"The prospect of vaccines returning life to normal injected wild hope into many of the least-popular assets ... The message is clear: things are looking better. But the Treasury market seems to have missed the memo. Yields leapt on the day of the Pfizer vaccine, but have since fallen back, with the 30-year yield—usually supersensitive to growth prospects—lower than at the start of the month ... This unusual divergence isn’t because the bond whisperers think the vaccine doesn’t matter. It is about the Federal Reserve and inflation, or rather the lack of it. After a decade when faster growth, low unemployment and zero interest rates did nothing to spark inflation, many no longer expect even extraordinary Fed action to push up prices faster ... Inflation prospects have barely budged, despite the boost to the economy a vaccine is expected to bring. The implied inflation rate calculated by comparing yields on Treasurys and on Treasury inflation-protected securities for the five years starting in five years’ time has risen only to 1.83% from 1.81% at the end of October, still below the 1.92% reached last month, the highest since August last year ... With inflation off the agenda, investors think the Fed will stamp down hard on any rise in yields, because of the drag on growth from higher borrowing costs." https://www.wsj.com/articles/stocks-say-covid-recovery-is-nigh-bonds-tell-a-different-story-11606572182
Virus behavior indicates a number of states will have to enact shutdowns which have a significant impact to economic activity
30yr currently at 1.69%. +1% to less than 2, -1% to 2-2.5
Currently 1.75 trending upwards. +1% to 2-2.5, -1% to less than 2
30 year up to 1.6% on vaccine news. Assuming a 60 bps yield volatility, that gets you to something like a 4% chance of rates climbing above 2% by year end. Seems unlikely, but non-zero.

Covid restrictions will be lifted in the next 6 months due to too big damage on the economy and employment and resulting repercussions. Or there will be a vaccine and/or antibody medicines or other somewhat effective treatments. The restrictions are bad for the economy, not the covid itself and thus the economy will start growing again in 2021, but the debt levels on businesses and individuals is too high for significant FED rate hikes. Even little hikes have a contrarian effect when the debt levels are high. Thus, I don’t believe the FED to fear for overheating of the economy in 2021 and it will pursue dovish monetary policy. Finally, for an investor this means that waiting for a future Treasury is not profitable and she can invest already, which drives demand now and keeps yields below 2.5.
Implied volatility suggests a 1-2% chance. Unlike Trump's election in 2016, Biden's won't be a surprise, so don't think it's likely to set off a rise in yields the same way.
Implied volatility suggests a 2.5% chance, which I'm increasing due tot he election (40 bps move in yields certianly seems possible and is what happened post Trump,)
60 bps move would be large but possible (is what happened when trump was elected for example)

Passage of time makes the deviation from current levels less probable. US election discomfort will likely cause govt bonds to be deemed attractive hiding places and rightly or wrongly, US Ts will be part of that - pushing ylds down.

Yields return to June levels, still far away from 2.00 but there is now a real chance of a Treasury sell-off despite ongoing deflationary pressures from Covid-19. People are complacent, as shorting bonds has been the "widow maker" for decades - but do not underestimate the volatility of the 30-Year once it starts moving. Tiny changes in rates make for big changes in the notional. From today's Financial Times (Prospect of spending splurge wakes up sleepy US bonds):
"The $20tn Treasuries market had grown sleepy in the months since the US Federal Reserve cut policy rates to zero to tackle the financial effects of corona-virus. Expected volatility, as measured by the ICE BofA Move Index, hovered around record lows and the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield barely budged from about 0.6 per cent, aside from a brief spike in June. But Treasuries have broken free from that slumber in recent days with long-dated yields rising sharply since the start of the month to their highest levels since June. A handful of fund managers warn this may be the start of a much sharper sell-off in US government debt with the benchmark 10-year note potentially flirting with levels last seen before the coronavirus outbreak tore through financial markets. “If you look at where 10-year yields were going into the crisis, they were close to 2 per cent,” said Zachary Squire, chief investment officer at hedge fund Tekmerion Capital Management. “There is no reason why we can’t get back there in a matter of months.”" https://www.bloomberg.com/markets/rates-bonds/government-bonds/us
Regular update, no change. 1.401% today, no significant change to be expected in the nearer future.

Fed is trying to get inflation, but so are all the other major central banks and no one has managed to really counter the downward direction of rates (long or mid curve). Why should the US be 2x the UK 30yr?  Germany negative... even Italy is below 2.

Last week has shown (again) that the 30Y can move fast once it starts to move. What I find remarkable is that this volatility occurred on the base of an entirely expected, scripted speech and in really benign market conditions - imagine there is some real inflation suddenly popping up somewhere.. Not going to crazy on this question yet, though, as deflationary forces "should" dominate until March or so. https://www.tradingview.com/chart/?symbol=TVC%3AUS30Y
Today: 1.247. NO reason to believe, it will be above 2 in less than 5 months.

Low real rates is not an uncommon policy response to high debt levels, especially when the monetary authority is shifting away  from an inflation targeting regime. We have high debt levels throughout the developed world central bank efficiency has been altered and partially neutered by their own policy actions and balance sheet expansion. We are already seeing a surge of fiscal spending and a blurring if Treasury and central bank distinction. Inflation will not come this quickly, as a recession would suggest. I would bet on past experience with low real rates, financial repression, followed by inflation, and intermixed with defaults.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.

It seems very unlikely now that the 30 year yield will rise until the end of the year because the economy is stronger than expected; if we see higher rates it would be on the back of a 'unsustainable debt' narrative and bond volatility would be sharply higher - therefore allocating equal probabilities to the outlier brackets.

US debt is like an adjustable rate mortgage. The treasuries keep getting rolled over. The federal government cannot afford a high interest rate on $25 trillion + in debt. Powell has made it clear that they will print as much money as is necessary.  They will buy as many treasuries as necessary. Eventually inflation will rise and force treasury rates up, but it is doubtful this will happen by the end of the year.  This is not a market driven price. This a completely controlled price, and we know exactly what the people who control this price will do.
Jerome is driving this bus, with unlimited fuel he can cause any rate to happen. Low, but not negative rates are needed.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-06-16/harvard-s-rogoff-negative-rates-should-be-on-the-table-for-fed-video Could drive 30 yrs market rate first down harshly, and then, counter-intuitively and unexpectedly, up, since negative rates are a clear as possible sign of an economy in a prolonged crisis, and could thereby affect long-term trustworthiness and ratings in the USA as a debtor. Decline in attractiveness of US government benchmark bonds as an asset class, in credit ratings and credit quality, and the looming possibility of a credit default (be it of technical nature or for any minor reason) could be the result.
As a long-term effect of this set of parameters end externalities, after inverting for a few weeks, the whole term structure of US government bonds could become steeper by end of the summer 2020, and then shift upwards amid a deteriorating economic outlook and creditworhtiness.

Tweeking a couple points. Yields will remain low. The United States 30 Year Bond Yield is expected to trade at 1.48 percent by the end of this quarter, according to Trading Economics global macro models and analysts expectations. Looking forward, we estimate it to trade at 1.59 in 12 months time.
Trading Economics › united-states
Another dramatic directional change. Lower for longer still works in this context.

On the move, from 1.17 to 1.67 in last six weeks.
https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/bond/tmubmusd30y?countrycode=bx
The 30yr is creeping upwards June 4=1.607 % at this rate could easily surpass 2 by year end. Who Knew?
It would take a magical economic boom to boost this.

https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/?symbol=US30Y
1.32 at the moment and given the debt loads on individuals and governments plus the loss of exuberance for spending or congregating I expect we are in for a long haul. 2-5 years. Have a niece who is studying this for the government at a think tank and she concurs.

The yield on the 30 Year that we are seeing (https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/?symbol=US30Y) have not been seen even during the 2008-2010 Global Financial Crisis. I believe it should hold this range unless there is a significant improvement in the economy, which is unlikely to happen before 2021.

To say 30-year yields will certainly be sub-2% at year end is crazy (with that said I still see it as the most likely scenario). The cyclicality of the yield curve sees long bond yields rise even as short-end rates stay pegged (i.e., curve steepening). With all the reflationary policy that has been put in place, all you need is a shift in expectations (e.g., the economy re-opening) to see long bond yields jump.
"Interest rates on federal borrowing are expected to remain quite low in relation to rates in recent decades." https://www.cbo.gov/publication/56335
No reason to see it rise given expectations for weak economy and low inflation. Small chance for uptick depending on size of issuance.
with the current situation regarding SARS COV 2 it seems very unlikely investors will abandon the security of US treasuries to the point where the yield rises above 2%

April 14= 1.38%
We'll still be in recovery, dropping money from helicopters in the hope that someone will go outside and pick it up.
There will be no "v" in the word recovery. Might even be a w.
Federal Reserve is not going to stop buying treasuries. The only trick they have is to print money and this time they're not going to be able to stop.

Current rate is 1.43%
Clearly it will be sub 2 for a period.     The question is will it be at the end of december. 
There will be a fairly massive rebound where money will go into stocks - I imagine sometime around may. But I think economic activity gets depressed for a long time.
March 25 = 1.414 %  and we are still not all locked down.
Historical baseline higher than 2 but these are exceptional times. Economy may recover enough to put it above 2 in December.
March 23 = 1.383 % As the Fed announces new tools to prop up the market.

March 20 = 1.47 %
What will normalicy look like in December 2020, I don't think we know. 
A lot will have been lost and rebuild will be happening, hopefully.

March 18 = 1.763 % UNCH (0) we've had our bounce off an incredible low.
December is a long way off, and the intra-day bouncing is off-puttting. Clearly in new territory with no guide posts.
The 30yr is at 1.53 trending up over the last week. -10% to below 2.

March 12 =1.464 %
We bounced off the bottom. Is there another shoe to drop?
Perhaps when the US begins testing and reporting the true extent will start to be known - will that be the other shoe?
Yikes............not negative yet....but........when the high for the day is 1.00x and low is 0.875 you have got to wonder?
Even sharpest historcial recoveries have been up ~1.5% after 9 months. today yield is 0.9% so max likely is 2.4%
The current 30 year treasury yield as of February 28, 2020 is 1.65%.
update given covid-19 and fed response

Shifting polarities. Assuming Mr. Market continues to scream for more interest rate cuts as the economy stalls, the Fed could accomodate and drive the short term rates way below 1, which may have a knock on effect on the long term rate. Then we'd be in the same boat as Japan and Europe with most of the water drained out of the pool.
Highly uncertain due to coronavirus impact on inflation, growth and Fed reaction function
Range of 2-2.5% would be lower, except that curve might steepen with new QE.

Forming a new base rate. For the last 2 or so years the spread between the 3 month and 30 yr treasury yield has be ~1% or less and spending most of that time at a .5% spread or less. The 3 month treasury is currently .66%. Assuming these two conditions stand, it is much more likely than not that the 30 yr is less than 2.00 at the end of the year (80%). https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=knI
emergency 50 pt rate cut this AM
Yay.  Another forecast I forgot I had.

Over a 5-year history on 30 year t-bills, there looks to be a lower bound of 2%. Why won't the numbers go lower? I'm not sure, but I bet that, as the return goes down, lots of other investments come into consideration, moving demand away from t-bills and keeping the return at a sort of low-level equilibrium.

"Fear that the coronavirus will slow global growth has helped push down Treasury yields in recent weeks. Other factors include persistently soft inflation, which has limited one of the main threats to the value of longer-term Treasurys, analysts said." https://www.wsj.com/articles/treasury-to-sell-30-year-bonds-at-record-low-yield-11581614475
I believe it will hold around 2.3 until after US elections.

The US economy is at least from a macro perspective is strong and fundamentally sound. Investors like safety in an increasingly unpredictable world. Ironically, a large cause of the uncertainty is the unpredictable nature of US policy under Trump and the lack of trust that Trump will maintain previous US positions and not undercut everything with a tweet.

Adjusting down after latest auction results. Although I expect virus risks to subside, demand is high, and the principle risk (inflation is expected to remain low). That being said, if global pandemic fears don’t reflect the bottom for yields, I don’t know what does
Trend growth in the USA is migrating to lower and lower levels, thus long term yields should follow GDP.    Inflation is a big risk to the forecast.  Current 30yr yield on 2/12/20 was 2.077%..

Rates are 1.57% now (Feb 2020).  If rates are raised half a percent twice that would get them above 2.5%.
There is some pressure to get rates up now to give the fed flexibility to lower them again in the face of oncoming recession.  On the other hand Trump is exerting pressure not to raise rates before the election.  After the election, this pressure diminishes, but the likelihood of recession increases.  Considerably, I believe, but I'm doubtful much of this threat will have kicked in by December 31st.
Recession probability upcoming. May drop before end of year, which would push rates low but slowly increase.

The Fed’s most recent intervention in financial markets, meanwhile, has become a hot topic on Wall Street. Powell said the Fed would gradually taper its $60 billion of T-bill purchases once the level of bank reserves exceeded $1.5 trillion. This process will take place gradually. He stressed the Fed would be flexible about its overall balance sheet policy. Financial markets were spooked in late 2018 when Powell suggested the Fed’s balance sheet plans were on “automatic pilot.” The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.08%  closed up only 11.60 points at 28,734, well off up the highs of the trading session. The benchmark is 614 points below the record close hit on Jan. 17. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.02%   closed down 2.84 points to 3,273.40, the low point of the trading session. Yields on the 10-year Treasury note TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.66%  sank to 1.584%, which is 29 basis points below its closing price on Jan. 2.
.

https://www.marketwatch.com/story/fed-holds-benchmark-interest-rate-steady-sees-economy-growing-at-moderate-pace-2020-01-29

The outside view is in favor of the 2.50% - 3% range. As for the inside view, I see two main drivers: 1. The economy - my strong baseline is for more of the same, neither accelerating nor slowing down too much. This favors the current range of 2%-2.50%. It will take major acceleration or slowdown to drive the yield outside it. (The current weakness seems caused by the new Wuhan virus, but I'd say this is temporary).  2. The outcome of the US presidential election:
 -  A Trump win will send bond yields up as money would flow into the stock market and out of the bond market. Given that the range 2-2.50 is fairly wide, I'd say the 30-yr bond yield will end the year with 70% probability still in the 2-2.50 range and 30% above 2.50.  (This assumes that in the eve of the elections the yield will be close to the mid-point of 2.25%).
 -  A Trump loss will likely do the opposite, driving the yield down. I would assume that the Democratic winner would then send calming messages to the markets. I'd assign then a 20% probability that the yield would end 2020 below 2% and 80% - in the 2 - 2.50% range.
 - Finally, for the moment I stay agnostic on the presidential elections, assigning 50 percent to a Trump win.
Historic yields tend to average out.
Wandering between 2.26 and 2.90 for the last year.

The recent trend since August 2019 is gently upward, contrary to the overall trend since 2006 which has been mainly downward. My current forecast is based on blended probabilities taken from the two trends with equal weight.

Using frequencies of daily closing yields from the past year as the base rate for now. To consider:
- does looking at frequencies of %age changes differ significantly from the above?
- how could potential interest rate changes by the Fed influence the outcome?
- what other economic or other trends are likely for next year that have could have an impact on the outcome?

I am tightening my forecast - stability reins in the short term. However, year end closing and tidying postions for reporting may cause a dramatic swing in the final week of the year.

Since the first FED rate cut in july the term premium is slowly grinding higher. I expect this to continue in the next few months as it did in other periods which are comparable to the current circumstances.
less than 2 recession, narrower odds on stability/slight uptick (no view), above 3 is non-recession scenario
Initial guess- combination of crowd forecast and @petequinn.

STRONGER FOR LONGER! Policy majors still subscribe to the notion that QE could eventually work. Meanwhile rates have fallen, and are likely (albeit not certain) to continue to do so. With the business cycle heading towards recession, growth is set to slow between now and end-2020. A flight-to-safety effect is further likely to case for remaining bullish on (sovereign) bonds.

I've grabbed historical data from 1977, and focussed on the trend since 2006, which shows a linear downward trend, with some fluctuation about a best fit trend aiming squarely for 2.15%. I've drawn parallel trend lines aiming at 2.0, 2.5 and 3.0%, and counted the days above and below each of those trends since 2006 and obtained the following:
below 2.0% trend: 1096 of 3466 days (31.6%)
between 2.0 and 2.5%: 1514 days (43.7%)
between 2.5 and 3.0%: 847 days (24.4%)
over 3.0%: 9 days (0.3%)

Adjusting up and break-even rates rise. CPI number will be released this week and are expected to show inflation above 1.5%. Fed is also saying that tightening will not happen until we see persistent inflation above target. Market is also pricing in trade talks not getting worse as the most likely outcome.  I think the last two weeks of the scope will be volatile - especially with low liquidity during the holidays. Adjusting up since I think we will see the 30-year break 2.5 this week

What will be the closing yield for the 30-year U.S. Treasury on 31 December 2020? 
Yields bottomed in Aug just below 2% and have risen since and today Nov 8 sit at 2.42%. Going forward rates should return to the norm for the year. Year-end book closing may drive rates higher or lower for the last day.

The US will continue to out perform europe over the next year, and will redress some of the us/china trade imbalance.   Capital will come to the US.    The stock market will continue to rise.  In normal times, I would say 0,10,20, 70.  However, europe will continue to be a problem area.   Rich, and large institutional investors will flee q.e. happening in Europe, and europe probably goes into a recession. Some of that money will flee to bonds.   QE will moderate US bonds. The size of the US budget deficit will cause issues around the witching dates.  The Fed *should* cut rates but I don't know that it will have the brains to recognize.   Capitol will be coming to the US and there is not reason to pay more interest than required. Outlook:  till the end of the Q4:  increasing bond yields.  Spring - Summer Europe starts warning of recession.  Good year for the US.
